Glossary

  • 2FA / Two-Factor Authentication
    A second step of security (like a code on your phone) used in addition to your password. Makes accounts much harder to break into.

  • Audit (Security Audit)
    A check-up of a school’s or organisation’s computer systems to find weaknesses before criminals do.

  • Data Breach
    When private information (like IDs or bank details) is seen, stolen, or shared without permission.

  • Encryption
    A way of protecting information by turning it into secret code that only the right people can read.

  • Fake Platform / Fake Website
    A site that looks real but is created by scammers to steal information or money.

  • Identity Theft
    When someone uses your personal information (like passport or bank details) to pretend to be you.

  • Incident Response
    A plan that organisations follow when something goes wrong with data security, e.g., who to tell, how to limit damage.

  • Institutional Data
    Information that belongs to an organisation (like school exam papers, staff records, or budgets).

  • Malware
    Short for “malicious software.” A harmful program that can damage your computer or steal information.

  • Password Manager
    A safe app that remembers and stores all your different strong passwords so you don’t have to.

  • Personal Data
    Information about you, such as your name, ID number, address, or documents.

  • Phishing
    A fake email or message pretending to be from a real organisation, asking you to click a link or give details.

  • Privacy Settings
    Controls on apps or websites that let you choose who can see your posts, photos, or personal details.

  • Scam
    A trick designed to steal money or information. Often sent by email, text, or social media.

  • Social Engineering
    When criminals manipulate people instead of computers – for example, pretending to be a teacher or IT support to get your password.

  • Threat Landscape
    The overall picture of digital dangers at a certain time, like phishing, malware, or scams.

  • Urgency (Scam Tactic)
    A trick used by scammers where they pressure you to act fast: “final notice” or “reply within 24 hours.”

  • VPN (Virtual Private Network)
    A tool that protects your internet connection and makes it harder for others to track your online activity.
